header.title: THEURGIA GOETIA - Book II OF THE LEMEGETON

central_thesis: The text outlines a comprehensive system for commanding various classes of aerial spirits—including Chief Spirits (Emperors, Kings, Princes), Dukes, and their numerous Servants—to perform specific tasks, such as revealing hidden knowledge, manipulating the elements, or locating treasures. This is achieved through precise conjurations, the use of specific seals, directional alignment, and adherence to designated timing, primarily planetary hours, to compel obedience.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the 31 Kings or Princes and their subordinate spirits. It details their general offices, which include revealing hidden knowledge, facilitating transport, performing elemental tasks (Fire, Air, Earth, Water), and disclosing secrets of individuals. Spirits are classified as both good and evil, governed by Princes associated with specific compass points. The text emphasizes the necessity of wearing a Lamen and aligning operations with the spirit's directional abode for successful evocation, noting that seals and conjurations are unique to each spirit but follow a general form.

A foundational compass diagram illustrates the fixed and movable mansions of 20 Kings and Princes, providing a crucial visual guide for directional alignment during rituals. Carnesiel, identified as the 'most chief & great Emperor ruling the East,' is introduced as commanding vast numbers of Dukes and Ministring Spirits, though only 12 chief Dukes are detailed for practical use.

structure_content.chapter_title: Seals of Carnesiel and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: This part presents the principal seal of Carnesiel along with the individual seals of his 12 chief Dukes: Orvich, Armany, Benoham, Myrezyn, Vadriel, Bucafas, Bedary, Cumerzel, Zabriel, Capriel, Arifel, and Laphor. It notes the immense number of attendants for Carnesiel (60,000,000,000,000 Dukes) versus his individual Dukes (up to 300, sometimes as few as 10), and provides a template for their conjuration.

Caspiel, the 'Chiefest Emperor Ruling the South,' is introduced with his extensive hierarchy of 200 great Dukes, 400 lesser Dukes, and over a trillion Ministring Spirits. Caspiel's main seal is provided, followed by the seals of his 12 chief Dukes: Chariel, Maras, Temol, Budarijm, Camorr, Larmol, Ariaiel, Geriel, Ambri, Camor, Otiel, and Vusiel. The text warns that Caspiel's Dukes can be 'very stubborn & churlish'.

This section details Amenadiel, the 'great Emperor of the West,' who commands 300 great Dukes, 500 lesser Dukes, and a multitude of other spirits. Amenadiel's main seal and the seals for his 12 chief Dukes (Camiel, Vadras, Musiriel, Luziel, Lamael, Rapsel, Carifas, Zoeniel, Codriel, Amesiel, Nadroc, and Balsur) are given. Specific instructions on the planetary hours for calling Amenadiel's Dukes are included, emphasizing sequential calling.

Demoriel, the 'great & mighty Emperor of the North,' is presented with his vast retinue of 400 great Dukes, 600 lesser Dukes, and numerous servants. His main seal and the seals for his 12 chief Dukes (Armbiel, Monandor, Cabarim, Diriel, Burisiel, Carnol, Mador, Moder, Dubilon, Dabrinos, Churibal, and Chomiel) are listed. It's noted that his Dukes also have many servants, with specific conjuration similar to others.

Pamersiel, a chief spirit under Carnesiel ruling the East, commands a thousand spirits. The seals for his 11 chief Dukes (Madriel, Aneyr, Sotheans, Ebra, Madres, Abrulges, Ormenu, Itules, Rablion, Hamorphol, and Itrasbiel) are provided. These spirits are described as 'Evil & very false' but 'excellent in driving away Spirits of Darkness'. Instructions for their evocation include making a circle, using a Crystal Stone on 'Solomon's Table', and wearing the spirit's seal as a Lamen and the Table's seal on a girdle.

structure_content.chapter_title: Padiel (East & By South) and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: Padiel, a King under the Empire of the East, governs 10,000 day spirits and 200,000 night spirits. These spirits are characterized as 'naturally good & may be trusted'. No specific names or seals for his subordinate spirits are provided, as they cannot appear without Prince Padiel's permission.

Camuel, a King ruling the South East, commands various spirits for day and night. Seals are provided for 10 Day Dukes (Orpeniel, Pariels, Chamijels, Cariels, Budiel, Neriels, Elearys, Daniels, Citgaras, Omiels) and 9 Night Dukes (Asniels, Moras, Calyms, Dobiels, Todiel, Moriel, Nodars, Phaniels, Tuaros). These spirits are noted to appear 'very beautiful' and 'very courteously' both day and night.

structure_content.chapter_title: Asteliel (South & by East) and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: Asteliel, a King under Carnesiel, governs the South & by East, with 10 chief Day Spirits and 20 Night Spirits, each having 20 servants. Seals are provided for 8 Day Dukes (Mariol, Charas, Parniel, Aratiel, Cubiel, Aniel, Otiel, Othiel) and 8 Night Dukes (Sariel, Asahel, Aroam, Euriel, Chamos, Asphiel, Bufar, Melas). All are described as 'very courteous & loving & beautiful'.

Barmiel, the first chief spirit under Caspiel ruling the South, commands 10 Day Dukes and 20 Night Dukes, mostly with 20 servants each. Seals for 8 Day Dukes (Sochas, Kiriel, Cleansi, Carpid, Barbil, Acleror, Tigara, Mansi) and 8 Night Dukes (Berbis, Morcaza, Acereba, Ashib, Gabir, Carnet, Marques, Baabal) are listed. These spirits are characterized as 'very good & willing to obey'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Gediel (South & by West) and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: Gediel, the second spirit under Caspiel, ruling the South & by West, has 20 chief Day and 20 chief Night spirits, each with 20 servants. Seals for 8 Day Dukes (Cotiel, Naras, Sadiel, Agra, Assaba, Sabas, Reciel, Anael) and 8 Night Dukes (Sariel, Cirecas, Araon, Vriel, Aglas, Mishel, Rantiel, Bariel) are provided. These spirits are 'very loving and courteous, willing to do your will'.

Asyriel, ruling the Southwest, commands 20 great Dukes for day and night, with varying numbers of servants (from 40 down to 10). Seals are provided for 8 Day Dukes (Olitors, Carga, Buniels, Rabas, Arisat, Ariel, Cuopiel, Malugel) and 8 Night Dukes (Amiel, Cusrel, Marott, Onuel, Buter, Aspiel, Fiascua, Hamas). All are described as 'good natured & willing to obey'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Maseriel (West & by South) and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: Maseriel, ruling the West & by South, has 12 chief Day and 12 chief Night spirits, each with 30 servants. Seals are listed for 12 Day Dukes (Mayhue, Chares, Zeriel, Aliel, Azimel, Earviol, Assuel, Vescur, Roviel, Patiel, Atmot, Espoel) and 12 Night Dukes (Arach, Eliol, Sarmiel, Atriel, Baras, Nogoiol, Rabiel, Badiel, Naras, Eras, Amoyr, Sdvar). All are 'good natured & willing to do your will'.

Malgaras, ruling the West, commands 30 Day Dukes and 30 Night Dukes, mostly with 30 servants (some exceptions noted). Seals for 12 Day Dukes (Carimiel, Rabiel, Agor, Alisiel, Udiel, Boras, Meliel, Cabiel, Casiel, Barfas, Oriel, Arois) and 12 Night Dukes (Arac, Deilas, Cubi, Rabae, Aspiel, Zamor, Asper, Basiel, Libiel, Dodiel, Caron, Amiel) are provided. These spirits are 'very courteous & will appear willing'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Darochiel (West & by North) and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: Darochiel, ruling the West & by North, has 40 Day and 40 Night Dukes, with 24 chief Dukes mentioned (12 before noon, 12 afternoon), each having 40 servants. Seals are provided for 24 Day Dukes (Magael, Tubiel, Carciel, Asphor, Gudiel, Danael, Abriel, Arlino, Choriel, Corua, Emuel, Alshor, Lomor, Cavron, Etiel, Buciel, Morach, Suriel, Sovial, Omiel, Easgel, Diviel, Mamel, Lorgat) and 24 Night Dukes (Naliel, Ofisel, Soriel, Darbori, Patiel, Gayres, Vreniel, Pelusar, Budis, Liel, Paniel, Aroziol, Narsiel, Chadriel, Abael, Gariel, Momel, Maziel, Curfas, Cusijnd, Mosiel, Meroth, Pasiel, Lobiel). Instructions specify calling them by planetary hour. All are 'good nature' and 'willing to obey'.

Usiel, ruling the Northwest, commands 40 diurnal and 40 nocturnal Dukes, with varying servant numbers. Seals for 14 Day Dukes (Alimoris, Seafar, Ameta, Mapui, Amen, Amandiel, Herne, Barfu, Sadfar, Garnafu, Potiel, Hisiam) and 14 Night Dukes (Fabariel, Vsimel, Anfel, Asurel, Godiel, Almod, Barfos, Pathir, Burfa, Narad, Saddiel #1, Lasphoron, Ofsidiel, Ethiel, Adan, Saddiel #2) are presented. These spirits are 'very obedient & do willingly appear' and 'have more power to hide or discover treasure'. A unique instruction involves using 4 seals on virgin parchment for treasure protection.

structure_content.chapter_title: Cabariel (West & by North) and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: Cabariel, ruling the West & by North, has 50 Day Dukes and 50 Night Dukes, each with 50 servants. Seals for 10 Day Dukes (Satifiel, Peniel, Tares, Thalbor, Etimiel, Ladiel, Elitel, Parius, Cupher/Cuphir, Godiel) and 10 Night Dukes (Aforiel, Ugiel, Elijsam, Orijm, Morias, Cazsul, Aniel, Dubiel, Mador, Pandor) are given. Day spirits are 'very good & willing to obey,' while Night spirits are 'evil & disobediant & will deceive you if they can'.

Raysiel, ruling the North, has 50 Day Dukes and 50 Night Dukes with varying servant numbers. Seals for 16 Day Dukes (Baciar, Dubarus, Thoac, Armena, Sequiel, Alhadur, Sadar, Chanael, Teragh, Fursiel, Astiell, Betasiel, Ramica, Melcha) and 14 Night Dukes (Tharas, Vbiel, Thariel, Quibda, Paras, Belsay, Arayl, Morael, Culmar, Sarach, Lazaba, Arepach, Aleasy, Lamas, Sebach, Thureal) are provided. Day spirits are 'good & willing to obey,' while Night spirits are 'evil & stuborne & disobedient'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Symiel (North & by East) and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: Symiel, ruling the North & by East, commands 10 Day Dukes (720 servants each) and 10 Night Dukes (790 servants each). Seals for 10 Day Dukes (Asmiel, Larael, Chrubas, Achot, Vafros, Boniel, Malgron, Dagiel, Romiel, Musor) and 10 Night Dukes (Mafrus, Marianu, Apiel, Narzad, Curiel, Murahe, Molael, Richel, Arafes, Malad) are presented. Day spirits are 'very good and not disobedient,' whereas Night spirits are 'stuborn, and will not Appear willingly'.

Armadiel, ruling the North East Part, commands 15 chief Dukes, each with 1260 servants, callable day or night according to planetary divisions. Seals for all 15 Dukes (Alferiel, Pandiel, Orariel, Carasiba, Orin, Laiel, Samiel, Caluarnia, Massar, Asbibiel, Parabiel, Mafayr, Asmael, Oeniel, Iaziel) are provided. All are described as 'good by nature' and 'willing to do your will'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Baruchas (East & by North) and His Dukes
structure_content.summary: Baruchas, ruling the East & by North, commands 15 chief Dukes, each with 7040 servants, callable day or night by planetary divisions. Seals for all 15 Dukes (Buita/Quita, Baoxas, Sarael, Geriel, Melchon, Monael, Cauayr, Chubor, Aboc, Lamael, Cartael, Dorael, Ianiel, Decaniel, Pharol) are listed. All are 'good by nature' and 'willing to obey'.

Geradiel is introduced as a Wandering Prince who commands 18150 servants directly, without Dukes. His seal is provided. The method of evocation is to call him alone, with the number of servants varying by planetary hour (e.g., 470 servants for the first two hours, up to 13710 for the 5th/6th hours). These spirits are 'indifferent good by nature, and will obey in all things willingly'.

Buriel is another Wandering Prince, commanding many Dukes and Servants. His seal and the seals for his 12 Dukes (Merosiel, Nedriel, Almadiel, Futiel, Cupriel, Drusiel, Busiiel, Carmiel, Saruniel, Drubiel, Casbriel, Nastros) are given. These spirits are 'by nature evil' and 'hated by all other Spirits,' appearing 'Rugish' in the form of a serpent with a virgin's head, speaking with a man's voice. They are specifically called at night due to their aversion to day.

Hidriel, a Wandering Prince, commands 100 Great Dukes, 200 Lesser Dukes, and countless servants, with a focus on 12 chief Dukes (1320 servants each). His seal and the seals for his 12 Dukes (Morfatiel, Samiel, Chalmoriel, Dusiriel, Pesariel, Chamiel, Musuziel, Arbiel, Lameniel, Lusiel, Brackiel, Chariel) are provided. They appear as a serpent with a virgin's head and face, are courteous, willing to obey, and prefer waters and moist grounds.

Pirichiel, a Wandering Prince, has no Dukes but commands Knights (8 chief ones mentioned, each with 2000 servants). His seal and the seals for his 8 Knights (Damarsiel, Menaziel, Cardiel, Demediel, Almasor/Almariel, Hursiel, Nemariel, Cuprisiel) are given. These spirits are described as 'good by nature and will do your will willingly'.

Emoniel, a Wandering Prince, commands 100 Princes & Chief Dukes, 20 under-Dukes, and a multitude of servants, with 12 Chief Princes/Dukes (1320 under-Dukes/inferior spirits each) detailed. His seal and the seals for 12 Dukes (Ermeniel, Vasenel, Panuel, Masinel, Edriel, Cruhiel, Carnodiel, Armisiel, Dramiel, Caspaniel, Pandiel, Musiniel) are provided. These spirits are 'good by nature & willing to obey,' inhabit woods, and are called day or night according to planetary order.

Icosiel, a Wandering Prince, commands 100 Dukes & 300 Companions, with 15 chief Dukes (2000 servants each) for practical use. His seal and the seals for 15 Dukes (Machariel, Amodiel, Psichiel, Tianabriel, Tlanatiel, Zachariel, Zosiel, Nathriel, Acapsiel, Athesiel, Lerphiel, Vrbaniel, Cumariel, Heraciel, Munetiel) are presented. These spirits are 'good nature & will do what they are commanded,' primarily appearing in houses, and are called day or night based on 15 divisions related to sun rise/set.

Soteriel, a Wandering Prince, commands 200 Dukes & 200 Companions whose locations change annually. The text highlights 12 chief Dukes (1840 servants each), divided between two successive years. His seal and the seals for 12 Dukes (Inachiel, Amriel/Ainoel, Proxel, Prasiel, Marucha, Axosiel, Amodar, Caroel, Nadiusiel, Mursiel, Cobusiel, Penader) are provided. These spirits are described as 'good & very obedient'.

Menadiel, a Wandering Prince, commands 20 Dukes & 100 Companions. The text focuses on 6 Chief Dukes and 6 Under Dukes (300 servants each). His seal and the seals for 6 Chief Dukes (Larmel, Brassiel, Chamor, Benadiel, Charsiel, Samiel) and 6 Under Dukes (Barchiel, Armasiel, Baruch, Nedriel, Curaijn, Tharson) are given. Spirits are 'good nature & very obedient' and called by planetary motion, alternating between a Duke and a Companion each hour.

Macariel, a Wandering Prince, commands 40 Dukes and other servants, with 12 chief Dukes (400 servants each) described. His seal and the seals for 12 Dukes (Chaniel, Verpiel, Drusiel, Germel, Andras, Thirsiel, Caroel, Burfiel, Amadiel, Aromusij, Remijel, Naustuel) are provided. They appear in various forms, often as 'a dragon with a virgins head,' are 'good by nature and obedient,' and are called day or night according to planetary order.

Vriel, a Wandering Prince, commands 10 Dukes & 100 under-Dukes, with 10 chief Dukes (650 Companions/servants each) detailed. His seal and the seals for 10 Dukes (Chabri, Curmis, Darbos, Darpios, Narmiel, Hermon, Frasmiel, Adrnsis, Brymiel, Dragon) are listed. These spirits are noted as 'by nature Evil & will not obey willingly & are very false,' appearing as 'a serpent with a virgins Head & face'.

Bydiel, the final Wandering Prince, commands 20 Chief Dukes & 200 other Dukes, plus many servants, with 10 chief Dukes (2400 servants each) detailed, whose office and place change annually. His seal and the seals for 10 Dukes (Mudriel, Charobiel, Crucham, Andrucha, Bramsiel, Manasael, Armoniel, Persifiel, Lemoniel, Chremo) are given. These spirits are described as 'good & willing to obey,' appearing 'very beautiful in human shape'.

This crucial section provides specific conjuration formulas tailored for different ranks of spirits: Wandering Princes, Princes governing compass points, the four Emperors, Wandering Dukes, and Dukes belonging to compass-point Princes. The formulas are variations of a core 'I Conjure thee O thou Mighty & Potent Prince N...' statement, incorporating specific attributes and commands, and invoking numerous divine names. Instructions detail showing the spirit its seal and the 'Pentacle of Solomon' upon appearance, and the necessity of a formal license to depart, as outlined in Book I of the Goetia.

key_concepts.definition: A collection of grimoires or magical texts, with 'Theurgia Goetia' constituting its second book.

A specific branch of Solomonic magic focused on the evocation of aerial spirits, which are often of a mixed nature (both good and evil or indifferent), distinguished from pure Goetia (demonic evocation).

High-ranking, powerful spirits that preside over specific directional dominions (e.g., East, South, West, North) or are 'Wandering Princes' who move through the air. They govern legions of subordinate spirits.
Subordinate spirits operating under the command of the Chief Spirits or Princes. They carry out the specific tasks requested by the magician.

A magical breastplate or medallion, worn by the practitioner, bearing the specific seal or character of the spirit being invoked. It is explicitly stated as essential for compelling the spirit's obedience.
Unique sigils or symbols for each spirit, serving as their identifying mark and a tool for their command and control during evocation.

Specific geographical directions (cardinal and inter-cardinal) to which various Emperors and Princes are assigned. Practitioners must direct their conjurations towards the spirit's associated point of abode.
Specific temporal divisions of the day and night governed by planetary influences, which are crucial for the timing of certain spirit evocations, especially for specific Dukes under greater Princes.
A scrying device, typically a 4-inch diameter crystal, into which spirits are directed to appear and communicate with the practitioner. It is often placed upon 'Solomon's Table'.

A specific magical table, which is to be constructed and used in conjunction with a Crystal Stone, particularly for calling Pamersiel and his servants. Its seal is to be worn on the practitioner's girdle.
A protective and power-confining boundary drawn around the practitioner, as described in Book I (Goetia), essential for safety and control during spirit evocations.
The formal verbal ritual sequence used to summon, compel, and command spirits. It involves invoking divine names and stating the desired outcome.
Powerful names of God (e.g., Adonay, El, Elohim, Tetragrammaton, Primeumaton, Alpha, Omega) invoked during conjurations to assert authority over spirits and compel their appearance and obedience.

A magical device or symbol (as described in Book I of the Goetia) that must be shown to the summoned spirit upon its appearance as a sign of authority and for further compulsion, and again during its dismissal.

practical_system.description: The system described is a structured method for the evocation and command of aerial spirits, which are organized hierarchically under Emperors, Kings, and Princes, further subdivided into Dukes and numerous Servants/Ministers. These spirits are summoned to appear in a scrying medium (typically a Crystal Stone) or within a magical circle to perform various tasks. The nature of the spirits ranges from 'good and obedient' to 'evil and deceptive,' requiring the practitioner to discern their character and apply appropriate commands and protective measures.
tools: Solomon's Table (a specific magical table for operations)
Crystal Stone (a scrying mirror or crystal sphere)
Magical Circle (protective boundary, constructed as per Book I)
Pentacle of Solomon (a magical sigil of authority)
Girdle (worn with the seal of Solomon's Table)
Virgin Parchment (specifically for Usiel's treasure-hiding seals)
rituals: Preparation: The practitioner must make a magical circle (as detailed in Book I) and perform the ritual in an 'airy' place or an 'upper room of your house' for aerial spirits.

Tool Preparation: The operator must wear a Lamen bearing the specific spirit's seal on their breast. For certain operations (e.g., Pamersiel), a 'Solomon's Table' must be prepared, with its seal worn on a girdle, and a 4-inch Crystal Stone placed upon it.
Directional Alignment: Conjurations must be directed towards the specific compass point (e.g., East for Carnesiel, South for Caspiel) where the ruling Prince or King has their abode.
Timing: Evocations for specific Dukes often require adherence to particular planetary hours of the day or night, ensuring the spirit's presence and obedience.

Conjuration: The practitioner recites the specific conjuration formula for the desired spirit, which includes powerful divine names (e.g., Adonay, Elohim, Tetragrammaton) and explicit commands, repeating it until the spirit manifests.

Appearance and Command: Upon appearance, the spirit is commanded to take a 'fair & comely shape' and communicate with an 'intelligible voice'. The practitioner must show the spirit its seal and the 'Pentacle of Solomon' to ensure compliance.

Task Execution: Spirits are tasked with various offices, such as revealing hidden things, transporting objects, performing elemental manipulation, or finding/hiding treasure (e.g., Usiel's seals on virgin parchment).
Dismissal: Once the desired task is completed, the spirit is formally licensed to depart, as detailed in Book I of the Goetia.

relevant_quotes.text: The office of these Spirits is all one, for what one can do the others can do the same, they can show & discover all things that are hidden, and done in the world & can fetch & carry & do any thing that is to be done or contained in any of the 4 Elements, Fire, Air, Earth or Water, & also the secrets of Kings or any other persons or person, let it be in what kind it will.

These are by nature good & evil, that is the one part is good & the other part is Evil, they are governed by their Princes, & each Prince hath his abode in the points of the Compass, as is showed in the following figure, therefore when you have a desire to call any of the Princes or any of their servants, you are to direct your self towards that point of the Compass the King or Prince has his mansion or place of Abode, & you cannot well err in your operations
without that [the Lamen] the Spirit that has appeared will not obey to do your will.

Note: these Spirits [Pamersiel's] are by nature Evil & very false & not to be trusted in Secrets but are excellent in driving away Spirits of Darkness from any(thing) that is haunted (such) as houses, & to call forth Pamersiel or any of these his servants, make a circle in the form as is showed in the 1st. Book Goetia before going in the upper room of your house, or in a place that is Airy because these Spirits that are in this part are all Airy. You may call these Spirits into a Crystal Stone 4 inches (in) Diameter sett on a table made as followeth which is called the Secret Table of Solomon, having his seal on your breast & the girdle about your waist, as is showed in the Book Goetia, and you cannot err.

Usiel... have more power to hide or discover treasure than any other Spirits saith Solomon, that is contained in this book Theurgia Goetia, & when you hide & would not have any thing taken away that is yours, make these 4 seals in virgin parchment & lay them with the treasure or where the treasure lyeth & it will never be found nor taken away...
Cabariel... Day spirits are very good & willing to obey... Night spirits are by nature evil & disobediant & will deceive you if they can
Buriel... Spirits; they Appear Rugish; & in the forme of a Serpent with a Virgins head; and Speaketh with a mans voyce, they are to be called in the night, [because they hate the day]

When he appears, show him the seal & pentacle of Solomon saying, "Behold the Pentacle of Solomon which I have brought before your presence..." as it is showed in the first book Goetia at the latter end of the Conjurations, also when you have had your desire of the Spirit, license him to depart as is showed there in the book Goetia, &c.

critical_analysis.relevance: Theurgia Goetia - Book II of the Lemegeton is a cornerstone text in the grimoire tradition, specifically bridging classical Goetia with theurgical practices by focusing on aerial spirits of varying moral alignment. Its systematic classification of spirits by directional dominion (Emperors, Kings, Princes, Dukes) and their fixed or wandering natures provides a structured framework for interaction. The emphasis on specific seals, directional alignment, and planetary hours demonstrates a sophisticated magical system with practical applications beyond mere 'demonic' evocation, influencing later ceremonial magic. The text's detailed descriptions of spirit offices, including elemental control and treasure operations, highlight its practical utility, while the moral categorization of spirits (good, evil, indifferent) offers a nuanced perspective on spirit contact.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience for this work includes experienced ceremonial magicians, academic researchers in Western Esotericism, and practitioners of grimoire traditions. It assumes a foundational understanding of Solomonic magic, particularly the practical elements and protective measures outlined in Book I (Goetia), making it less suitable for absolute beginners. Practitioners seeking to expand their repertoire beyond traditional Goetia or those interested in spirit work involving elemental control, divination, or treasure finding would find this text invaluable.
